articles.title: FEBRUARY 1987
articles.summary: This document outlines the February and early March 1987 schedule for an astronomy organization, detailing general meetings with speakers like Robert Schaeffer discussing "The UFO Verdict" and Bernie Haisch presenting a "Grand Tour of the Solar System." It also includes plans for board nominations and elections, indoor astronomy classes, and multiple outdoor astronomical observation events, such as freeze parties and field expeditions to Henry Coe State Park and Fremont Peak State Park.
keywords: Grand Tour of the Solar System

articles.title: FIELD OF VIEW
articles.summary: This article announces several upcoming events for the SJAA, including a general meeting on February 7th featuring a presentation by Robert Scheaffer on UFOs. The same meeting will also host nominations and elections for five SJAA board positions. Additionally, it announces the 7th Annual Bay Area Astronomical Auction scheduled for May 2nd.

articles.title: DOORS WILL OPEN AT 2:00 PM
articles.summary: An upcoming event will open at 2:00 PM, featuring a wide variety of astronomical equipment for sale, including telescopes, eyepieces, books, and camera gear. Attendees are invited to buy and sell their own astronomical items, with pre-registration available to streamline the process for a fun and easy experience.

articles.title: BY: DON MACHHOLZ
articles.summary: This article reports on recent comet activity, including the discovery of Comet Levey (1987a) and the classification of Comet Lovas (1986b) as periodic. It reviews the 16 comets discovered or recovered in 1986, noting the average contribution from amateur astronomers and the increasing use of photographic methods. The document also provides observation details and ephemerides for Comet Sorrells (1986h) and Periodic Comet Halley (1982i).

articles.title: SEEKING COMETS
articles.summary: This article outlines the process for amateur astronomers who believe they have discovered a new comet. After observing a fuzzy, unlisted object showing motion, and recording its data, the observer should report it directly to the Smithsonian Astrophysical Observatory, the central clearinghouse for new comet, asteroid, nova, and supernova discoveries. The observatory encourages the discoverer to continue observing and confirming the object, often with the help of fellow astronomers, before final confirmation.

articles.title: COMET REPORTING INSTRUCTIONS
articles.summary: This document provides instructions for reporting a new comet discovery to the Central Bureau for Astronomical Telegrams at the Smithsonian Astrophysical Observatory. It outlines the crucial information required, including the object type, discovery date and time, precise celestial coordinates, magnitude, appearance, and estimated motion, along with the reporter's contact details. The article emphasizes using telex or telegram for submission, advising against mail or phone in most cases for efficient and accurate transmission.

articles.title: VOYAGER 2's CLOSEST APPROACH TO NEPTUNE INCREASED
articles.summary: Voyager 2's closest approach to Neptune on August 24, 1989, has been adjusted from 1200 kilometers to 4800 kilometers. This change was implemented to avoid potential hazards from orbiting rocks and radioactive particles around the planet.

articles.title: SPACE STATION AGREEMENT DELAYED BY DEFENSE DEPARTMENT
articles.summary: The U.S. Defense Department has reversed its stance, now seeking to protect its rights for research on the U.S./International Space Station, despite not yet identifying specific uses. This change in position has led to a delay in U.S. negotiations with international partners concerning cost and management sharing for the Space Station.

articles.title: SPACE STATION ORBITAL PLATFORM DOWNGRADED
articles.summary: The polar orbiting platform, an integral part of the space station, has been significantly downgraded from its original weight of 30,000-50,000 pounds to only 12,000 pounds. This reduction is primarily due to budget cuts and a decreased capacity for shuttle launches into high-inclination orbits.

articles.title: SHUTTLE ESCAPE SYSTEM PLANNED
articles.summary: NASA is planning a new escape system for the Space Shuttle, utilizing tractor rockets to pull astronauts from the orbiter's side hatch during gliding flight. Preliminary modification work has begun on Discovery, and the implementation of this system could be a critical factor for the timely resumption of shuttle flights.

articles.title: NEW SHUTTLE MANIFEST ISSUED
articles.summary: A new Space Shuttle manifest has been issued, scheduling the resumption of flights for February 18, 1988. The plan outlines 5 missions in 1988, followed by 10 in 1989, and 11 in 1990.

articles.title: AN OVERFUL OF OBSERVING SITES BY: DON MACHHOLZ AND RICH PAGE
articles.summary: This article reviews the Saratoga Gap site in the Santa Cruz Mountains as a potential location for astronomical observing. It provides detailed directions, describes the physical layout of the dirt parking area, and outlines conditions such as elevation, horizons, and various sources of light pollution. While noting its advantages like a large setup area and low wind, it also highlights challenges posed by traffic on Hwy 9 and moderate city glow.

articles.title: THE CELESTIAL TOURIST SPEAKS BY: JAY REYNOLDS FREEMAN
articles.summary: Dr. Jay Reynolds Freeman recounts his 1977 visit to NASA's Johnson Space Center to use a CDC 6400 computer for his experimental astrophysics thesis data. While there, he observed the intensive software development for rudimentary Space Shuttle flight simulators, which were stationary mockups used to test ascent and abort software. Impressed by the functional instruments and advanced displays, Freeman was eventually offered the chance to 'fly' the simulator himself.

articles.title: ASTRO ADS
articles.summary: This document, titled 'ASTRO ADS', features classified advertisements for used astronomy equipment. Items listed for sale include an Odyssey One telescope tube and cradle assembly (without optics) and several TeleVue eyepieces (17mm Plossl, 10.4mm Plossl, and a 15mm Widefield). Contact information is provided for each seller.

articles.title: Marketing Manager—
articles.summary: This document advertises a job opening for a Marketing Manager at Orion Telescope Center, identified as America's #1 Telescope Dealer. The role entails corporate responsibility for developing and implementing direct mail, catalog, and media marketing plans, requiring a highly organized individual with strong marketing background and knowledge in response analysis, lists, media, copy, production, printing, and art. Applicants are instructed to respond via mail.

articles.title: GENERAL MEETINGS
articles.summary: The SJAA holds monthly General Meetings and "Indoor Star Parties" at the Los Gatos Red Cross building in Los Gatos, California. These events provide a friendly environment for members to discuss astronomy, share telescopes, images, and engage in topics like astrophotography, deep sky observation, and telescope making. General Meetings are held on the 4th Saturday of each month, starting at 8 PM, with detailed directions provided for attendees.

articles.title: INDOOR STAR PARTIES
articles.summary: The article describes "Indoor Star Parties," which are monthly informal gatherings for amateur astronomers. These events offer opportunities to share telescopes and accessories, view astrophotography, attend an introductory astronomy workshop, and socialize. They also host SJAA board meetings and are held at the Los Gatos Red Cross Building.

articles.title: HENRY COE STATE PARK
articles.summary: This document provides detailed directions to the San Jose Astronomical Association's (SJAA) observing site within Henry Coe State Park, including specific route guidance from Hwy 101 and the locked gate combination (4585). It also offers practical advice for accessing the site, particularly for arrivals after dark, emphasizing safety and proper setup.

articles.title: FREMONT PEAK STATE PARK
articles.summary: Fremont Peak State Park is highlighted as a popular astronomical observing site, with detailed driving directions provided to Coulter Camp where the San Jose Astronomical Association (SJAA) and the FPOA's public observatory are located. The site is noted for significant astronomical activity, especially on clear new moon weekends, frequently attracting many telescopes. The document also includes information about the SJAA's monthly publication, "EPHEMERIS," and contact details for the association's officers and board members.

articles.title: SAN JOSE ASTRONOMICAL ASSOCIATION MEMBERSHIP APPLICATION
articles.summary: This document is a membership application form for the San Jose Astronomical Association (SJAA), outlining different membership options and their associated costs, including standard, membership with Sky & Telescope, and junior memberships. It provides fields for applicant information and instructions for submitting the form either at a meeting or via mail to the treasurer.

articles.title: Questionnaire (optional)
articles.summary: This document features an optional questionnaire designed to gather information about individuals' astronomical interests, telescope ownership, and areas of expertise where they might help others. The latter part of the document provides mailing information for a non-profit organization, likely the San Jose Astronomical Association, and is marked as "NEWS MATERIAL" with a "TIME VALUE — DATED" stamp.
